snippet: The judge said that the city had “no evidence” to make the deterrence claim, and called the argument “too speculative” to be admitted in a suit challenging the tactic’s constitutionality.
abstract: Judge Shira A Scheindlin of Federal District Court in Manhattan rules that New York City has no evidence to back claims by the Bloomberg administration that the small number of guns found by police officers during stop-and-frisk encounters shows the program is working as a deterrent, and not that the police are exercising poor judgement in deciding whom to stop; calls deterrence argument too speculative to be admitted in court by city's expert witness in a class-action lawsuit challenging the tactic's constitutionality.
lead_paragraph: The judge said that the city had “no evidence” to make the deterrence claim, and called the argument “too speculative” to be admitted in a suit challenging the tactic’s constitutionality.
